SustainabilityThur, 04 SeptemberChristopher WickliInvestor Relations OfficerWise plcSarah LewandowskiDirector Investor RelationsWed, 03 SeptemberDiana Martinez MoscossoSenior Manager, Investor Relations

- How do you assess current business momentum across your core product categories - GaN, SiC, LED, microLED, and optoelectronics? Where do you see the strongest near-term demand drivers?- Utilization rates among your customers remain a key concern. What visibility do you have into utilization of your installed base, and how does this feed into order timing?- On orders: H1 was strong, but you also noted potential softening later in the year. Can you elaborate on order trends into Q3 and Q4, by customer group and by region?- Your FY25 guidance was reiterated, but implies a clear margin recovery in H2. What are the main drivers for gross margin improvement - mix, pricing, cost savings, or absence of one-offs?- When do you expect to return to sustainable top-line growth at the latest?- On cash flow: you generated strong free cash flow in H1, and your cash balance is piling up. What are your priorities for deploying this cash - R&D, M&A, buybacks, or simply a buffer against cyclicality?- GaN remains relatively strong in 2025, and you have highlighted opportunities in data center power. Can you walk us through how GaN power devices are positioned in next-gen server architectures, and what this means for Aixtron tool demand?- On optoelectronics: orders have been strong recently, but is this sustainable? How much of this is linked to AI-driven datacenter demand?- MicroLED has long been discussed as a potential growth driver. With Apple stepping back and Meta reported to move forward, how do you currently frame this opportunity?- The 300mm transition: both for GaN and SiC, how do you see the timing of 300mm adoption, and what is Aixtron's positioning with respect to R&D tools and future high-volume platforms?- Competition from Chinese tool makers is often mentioned. How do you assess the capabilities of AMEC, and others? Where could they become credible competitors, and what barriers protect Aixtron?- In silicon carbide, you have pointed out idle capacity in Western markets. How long do you expect it will take for this to normalize, and what would be the trigger for renewed ordering?- Can you share more on your current R&D roadmap - priorities across GaN, SiC, opto, and microLED, as well as your engagement in emerging areas like 2D materials?- What benefits did you get from your newly opened R&C center so far?- Looking into 2026 and beyond, what optionalities should investors be aware of - whether in datacenter, automotive power, or new materials?- Do you consider bolt-on acquisitions? Would there be any technological competencies you would like to add?

- How do you see the distribution of volumes among different channels currently? Do you expect some of the volumes to move back to GDS from direct connect? How do you expect this to change your unitary revenues in Air Distribution?- What is your approach to winning new airline customers, especially in emerging markets?- How does your NDC offering differ from your competitors?- How does Nevio's modular approach create competitive advantages, and what feedback are you receiving from airlines?- As Nevio implementation scale, how should we think about the revenue ramp and margin profile compared to traditional PSS solutions?- How large is the addressable market for hotel central reservation systems, and what's your growth strategy?- How do you see Outpayce (payment platform) positioned within the broader travel payments ecosystems? What are the key growth drivers and how sustainable do you view this momentum? How does it create synergies with your other business divisions (considering the e-money license approval)?- You are 60% through your cloud transformation targeting early 2026 completion. What are the non-recurring costs, and how will this impact your cost structure?- How do you see your margin profile evolving post cloud migration?- How are you ensuring security across your cloud infrastructure? What percentage of your tech budget is dedicated to security? Do you see a shortage for cybersecurity talent?- Where are you seeing the strongest growth opportunities, particularly in APAC and emerging markets?- Google is integrating booking into its chat environment. How does this competitive dynamic compare to traditional OTA competition and how are you responding?- What are the main sensitivities around your 2025 guidance? Volumes, cost inflation, FX. Etc?- How do you view your mid-term targets presented at the CMD? During the last results presentation you mentioned those still hold on cc. What are the main downside risks to those targets in your view?- You have mentioned integrating GenAI into your platform. What is your AI and ML roadmap, and how are these technologies being integrated across your product suits? How will this differentiate you from competitors who are aggressively pushing GenAI?- How is Amadeus preparing for the shift toward autonomous travel agents that can shop and book on behalf of travelers? Will this favor suppliers or intermediaries like yourselves?- What is your capital allocation priorities over the next 2-3 years?- What areas are you most interested in for potential acquisitions or partnerships?

ams OSRAM (Buy, TP CHF 12.5)- What growth in auto LED do you anticipate as you ramp up new products (eg ALIYOS, EVIYOS) and benefit from the transition to ADB?- How you characterise automotive demand by region?- Do you see lengthening lead times as bookings improves in auto and industrial?- Have you started to supply your own in- house LED driver ICs into your LED lighting solutions?- Is there any credibility to the idea that microLED could be back on the agenda at some of the major consumer electronics OEMs, even if not Apple?- You recently started the process of selling assets with a value of more than €500m with the sale of the entertainment lighting business to Ushio. How soon can we expect further announcements to give investors more confidence that more deals can be completed before year- end?- What is the latest on the Kulim2 sale process given that 200mm manufacturing lines are not particularly in demand at present given low industry utilization?- What is your fab loading at present across your front- end and back- end lines?- How much of a cash flow headwind in 2026 will be paying back the Apple prepayment?- If ams ex Heptagon was generating \(\sim 20\%\) adjusted EBIT margin, and OSRAM ex Digital was generating a \(\sim 15\%\) adjusted EBIT margin, why is it so hard to get the current business back to \(15\%\) ?

Do you believe that TSMC has pulled in spend on 2nm or do you expect TSMC- related spend to grow steadily into 2026? How exposed are you to the challenges that Intel is experiencing around 18A, notably into 2026? Trailing- edge China spend appears to be under pressure from both stockpiling of tools and pressure for buyers to move to domestic equipment suppliers. What do you see into 2026? Is your silicon carbide epi business (LPE) better positioned that Aitxron owing to the BEV market moving rapidly to China? Both Lam and Applied appear to have made some in- roads into ALD, which has got them excited. Do you agree that your LT share in single- wafer ALD could moderate to around \(50\%\) ? Can you discuss the molybdenum and ruthenium opportunities in ALD. Do you agree that the slower ramp of backside power delivery limits the scale of revenue opportunities for now? How secure is your share gain opportunity in silicon epitaxy, especially in gate all around (GAA) applications? Is there a scenario where batch ALD has a comeback against single- wafer ALD? Does your gross margin trend back to the bottom- end of the range as the China mix fades into 2026? What should investors expect from your upcoming CMD in London? An updated range on 2027 to reflect new WFE spending, share and FX assumptions, but what else?

What do you think is the biggest variable in terms of major customers on whether 2026 is a growth year or not? You seem to have seen some pull in of China demand into H1 from H2. Does China normalise from here into 2026 to the LT target of \(20\%\) of sales? What is the roadmap around low NA EUV and pushing ASPs above €300m, for example via higher source power? What does that mean for low EUV gross margins? Is there a risk of high NA tools in the backlog being re- classified, pushed out or cancelled given that a high proportion are from Intel? What is your assumption around whether TSMC adopts high NA or not at A10? How do you see the risks around 4F2 in DRAM given the potential halving of EUV layer count that this could introduce? How much of high NA builds can be re- purposed for low NA - are sub- modules completely fungible ex the optics? Do you need to take a look at slowing headcount expansion or taking cost out? You bought back a lot of shares in Q1, slowed that spend in Q2, and have stopped buying shares through the summer period. Is this an indication of the level of uncertainty you are facing? The 2030 sales range is quite wide - given that WFE spend is under pressure, does that mean the lower end is more likely than the higher end of the range?

You are now ramping volumes at the first plant in Kulim (for AMD), how do revenues evolve over the next- few quarters given that (i) you are ramp one line at a time and (ii) there is a delay in revenue recognition from production to shipment. In terms of managing tail risks, how should investors think about the rise of new packaging technologies that aim to fully, or at least partially, replace ABF substrates, namely glass substrates, System- on- Wafer (SoW) and CoWoP (ie 'on PCB'). Conversely, do these new packaging technologies offer AT&S opportunities to enter new packaging domains? What is your maximum capacity (in terms of sales), and how does this split between your facilities in China, Malaysia, Austria, etc. How does this compare to your current utilization at your largest facilities, for example, in Chongqing, China? In light of risks that your largest customers (ie Apple, Intel) continue to diversify supply away from China, how should investors think about ongoing underutilization at your largest facilities (Chongqing) and risks that such facilities become orphaned assets over time? How do you manage this risk, and does it involve shifting production away from China, to say, the second plant at Kulim (which is currently a shell). When do you expect the IC Substrate market to return to sustainable growth following AI spending crowding out CPU spending in the server market? Can you comment on the current pricing environment in IC substrates and PCBs? Has supply/demand become more balanced in recent quarters, and how do you expect these dynamics to change? How should we think about your AI exposure today and how that may evolve over time? Currently only Ibiden and Unimicron are qualified at Nvidia for CoWoS, do you expect to eventually get qualified? Or is your AI story more tied to custom ASIC vendors (ie Marvel, Ampere, Broadcom) ramping volume at your new facility in Leoben, Austria? How should investors think about your opportunity in edge AI, given you have \(50 - 70\%\) exposure to smartphone, PC & notebooks. How is your likely allocation changing at the major smartphone OEMs such as Apple? Is there any change to the preference for three or four suppliers? Can you discuss your opportunities in automotive and industrial segments? What are the key drivers here over the next few years?

H1 order intake was below the prior year and growth in new contractually secure cloud slowed somewhat in Q2. How should we think about order intake in H2? Are there differences in demand between Enterprise vs. SMB, DACH vs. international markets, and existing vs. new customers?- You mentioned deal slippage in Q2. Can you comment on the magnitude of those deals? When do you expect to close these deals?- Was the strong drop in license revenues in Q2 primarily driven by macro factors, or were there other factors playing into this as well (e.g., incentives to encourage the cloud migration)? How do you balance the short- term impact from lower license sales versus your intention to switch to a cloud- based model?

Can you provide an update on your investment and hiring plans? What are your expectations for investments/hirings in H2? Are there any delays in your investment plans? Should we anticipate further investments in FY26? How should we think about the margin in FY26?- You are facing attrition, somewhat offsetting your hirings. What are the drivers of this, and what measures are being implemented to address it?- Given the ramp- up time for sales personnel (6- 12 months for Enterprise, 3- 6 months for SMB), when do you anticipate seeing an increase in order intake and subsequent revenue contributions from recent hires?- Beyond hiring, you're also reorganizing sales processes. What progress has been made, and do you expect this to be completed in FY25? Have you observed any impacts on sales performance from these new processes?- You've announced a new CRO joining in November. What is the reason for this change? What implications does this have for your growth strategy?

Margin: What are the moving parts behind your margin guidance ( \(\geq 31\%\) )? Mid- term guidance: Where do you expect the growth acceleration in FY26 and FY27 to come from? Where do you see upside and downside risks? Cloud migration: Can you provide an update on your cloud migration? What percentage of your customer base has been migrated, and what is the typical revenue uplift realized from migrating on- prem customers to cloud? SAP cooperation: Progress with your SAP cooperation seems slower than you originally anticipated for FY25. What are key challenges, what steps are being taken, and when do you expect to see a meaningful improvement? New features and monetization: You've announced several promising new features (incl. AI), to be released in the coming quarters. What has been the initial customer feedback? How do you plan to monetize these features? When do you anticipate them contributing to revenue? M&A and long- term story: Your ambition for E400M in revenue by 2030 includes a semi- organic component involving acquisitions. Are you currently evaluating any potential targets? What size are you targeting and are you focussing on M&A for market entry or product improvements?

In your Q2 results call, you talked about some stabilisation in market conditions vs. the peak uncertainty / disruption you saw at the end of Q1/ start of Q2. In Q2, you reported revenue decline of \(- 13\%\) yoy vs. \(- 38\%\) in Q1 \(- 18\%\) adjusted for AutoStore as a Service deals). Is your expectation that revenue growth for the rest of the year would not worsen from the declines you saw in Q2?

Some of the colour you gave at the results included a relatively strong Europe which accounted for over \(50\%\) of orders in the period. You also flagged that over \(60\%\) of the orders were with existing customers. Will it be possible to give a sense of the impetus for these deals - ie. were they planned expansions that were delayed, new sites, any sectors in particular that were strong? Any reason you see why Europe was stronger than the rest of the regions?

Your systems are sold through partners. How much leeway on pricing do your partners have in terms of marking up your products? Has there been any change in pricing behaviour amongst your partners in this more challenging period to stimulate demand (i.e more discounting?)

North America revenues were still down \(30\%\) yoy in Q2 and accounted for c. \(22\%\) of revenues having been as high as c. \(40\% +\) in the past. You did however say forward indicators are looking better. Could you please elaborate on this? Which sectors are showing more signs of life?
How concerned are North American customers on tariffs? How much has it dampened appetite for warehouse automation solutions?

You have now discontinued the B1 business line and wrote of \(8.5m\) in Q2. How many customers are going to be impacted by it - can you transition them to existing solutions? Are there other product rationalisations you can make to drive efficiency?

You have now started selling AutoStore on a "rental" model rather than capex. AutoStore- as- a- Service orders were \(27m\) in Q1 and \(7m\) in Q2? Do you get a sense of the run- rate of orders from here? Are all the orders with 3rd Party Logistics (3PL) customers - as you mentioned this model seems to resonate most with them? Are any shuttle systems sold on a rental basis? Who are you typically pitching against in this model? Contract length for AaaS is 3- 8 years. How does the cumulative revenue over this period compare against the revenue you would have received on Day 1 on a capex model? As this is a rental model, the system sits on your balance sheet for the duration of the contract. At the end of 3- 8 years, is your expectation that the contract will just renew and therefore be an evergreen contract? Or that the customer will buy it at the depreciated price?

Historically, you have been taking share from shuttle and mini- load systems in the market for light AS/RS. How do you think you have fared in the last 12- 18 months against these more established solutions? Some of the shuttle providers have manufacturing bases in the US. How do you think tariffs have impacted the perception of price / value in your North American current and potential customers re the AutoStore solution vs. shuttle systems? You mentioned that since your CMD in Oct 2024, you have added c. 100 new logos, including several strategic accounts with significant long- term potential. Of the c. 1200 unique customers you currently have, how many would you describe as strategic accounts? Over 5- 7 years, how much cumulative revenues would you expect a strategic account to generate? Generally speaking, how far gone are you in educating the market in your differentiation/ advantages over competition? In the high throughput segment, is your performance seen as "up there" with the performance of shuttle systems? In the AGV (Autonomous Guided Vehicle) and AMR (Autonomous Mobile Robot) space, is your strategy to partner with these systems or would you be interested to develop /acquire your own offering?

You have reduced costs by \(\) 10m\(annually - could you discuss the areas where this was cut? Also, you talked about reinvesting some of the savings in areas of growth. Could you elaborate what these areas are? What are the key risks to gross margin and how do you mitigate against them? In an environment where you are growing at\) 10\% + \(, what is the level of adj. EBITDA margin you can sustain? As you continue to generate more cash, what is the plan on the balance sheet? If you were to look at areas of bolt on acquisitions, what would be the criteria or areas you would be looking at?

BE Semiconductor (Buy, TP EUR 140)- How do you see developments in hybrid bonding over the next 6 months? Should we expect a large order from TSMC in H2? What about from Micron, Samsung and/or Intel?- Will these larger hybrid bonding orders likely be in smaller batches of let's say 25 units at a time, or could they be much larger?- What insertion timing do you see for hybrid bonding at HBM, is it likely to be partial insertion for HBM4E, most probably at 16- hi?- How do you see the risks around JEDEC standard changes with regards to HBM?- What is the level of engagement on hybrid bonding from companies like Mediatek and Qualcomm, which primarily address the PC and smartphone domains?- Have you seen any changes at Intel, with regards to payments or roadmaps that suggest the company is under major stress?- Can you discuss the competitive threat posed by the Koreans such as Hanmi, SEMS and Hanwha, as well as other Western competitors like ASMPT/EVG and SUSS/SET in hybrid bonding?- Can you discuss developments around your TCB Next platform, and the path to let's say \(>100m\) of sales?- What signs of cyclical recovery give you hope for the mainstream business in 2026?- Is it hard to imagine the smartphone business in domains like optics going back to the boom times of old?

- When do you expect customer demand from your smaller customers to markedly improve again?- How fast can a positive impact from the stimulus package the German government is currently finalizing materialize in your P&L?- After Microsoft changed its fee structure, are there other suppliers also trying to renegotiate their contracts with you?- Do you envisage your two divisions (IT E-Commerce / IT System House & Managed Services) to develop in sync or is there a chance that one outperforms the other short- to medium-term?- When do you envisage your German business will grow significantly again?- The two downward revisions of your FY24E guidance were a negative surprise and your FY25 guidance continuously is very vague; how good is your visibility currently and when do you expect to see clearer?- Is there a risk that you have to implement cost cutting measures?- How does the current order intake/backlog situation look?- Is there a chance that your back-end margin can improve again in FY25E- Where are you with your own cloud solutions business. Will it continue to grow very significantly and what is its EBT margin?- How do you view the business outlook and growth potential for (hybrid) cloud solutions for SMEs in general?- Is your Cybersecurity business gaining in size/importance? Is it high-margin?- How do you see M&A potential going forward? Will you foremost focus on adding regions or product categories?- What do you intend to do with the cash you are generating? Rethink your dividend policy (target payout ratio 33%), do share buybacks or more/large M&A?- Do you expect to be able to lower your NWC further?- How do you feel you are positioned in terms of ESG considerations?

- What opportunities do you see for expanding services across the combined client base of both organizations? i.e. immediate cross-selling opportunities for WNS capabilities and vice versa.- How does the combined entity position against competitors like IBM, Accenture, and TCS in the AI powered BPS space?- What are the key integration milestones to realize the EPS acceleration in 2026 and 2027? What is your roadmap for integrating WNS' 64.6k professionals across 64 delivery centers with Cap's existing operations while maintaining service quality? Does this acquisition change how you think about delivery mix for European and North American clients?

- As GenAI drives productivity gains in IT services, how do you see this affecting your ability to defend pricing in application development and managed services? Do you expect a structural shift in your revenue model?- Which industries are showing the strongest demand for AI transformation, and how are you developing sector-specific AI capabilities?- Are you seeing companies budget AI as CapEx or OpEx?- What's the shelf life of AI solutions build today before they need substantial re-architecture? How does this affect client lifetime value calculations?

- Despite headwinds, what opportunities do you see in manufacturing digitalization and industry 4.0 initiatives?- Are you seeing pricing pressure in recovering sectors?- To what extent do public sector contracts in Europe offset cyclical IT spending downturns or are those also now being reprioritized?- How do you see demand trends diverging between Europe, North America, and APAC over the next 12-18 months?

- After your recent acquisition, are you shifting from capability-building to scale/market consolidation plays? Beyond AI and BPS, what capability gaps are you most likely to fill through acquisition?

- What would be the downside/upside risk to guidance?- With Gen AI reducing costs but also pricing, how do you preserve EBIT margin expansion beyond efficiency programs?- How do you think about FCF conversion in the mid-term? Are there structural elements of your WC cycle that you see improving?- What trends are you seeing in attrition and reskilling needs, and how are these affecting delivery costs?

Elmos Semiconductor (Hold, TP EUR 85)- Can you discuss your bookings trend in the third quarter – have you seen re- stocking continue at tier- 1s and OEMs?- Which particular design win activity is giving you the most encouragement for share gains into 2026?- Do you see any opportunity from increasing chip pricing into 2026?- Your leading foundry supplier, TSMC, has been pulling back from lagging- edge capacity at 0.18mu – how do you see foundry supply at the lagging- edge from other foundries outside of China?- Magnachip, one of your foundries, is now up for sale, having slashed capex. Is that a concern to you?- Can you discuss your localization strategy in China, and how could local competition could be a risk over time?- Can you discuss the opportunities in China to take share from US suppliers? Which product categories offer up the most opportunity to you here?- Which automation level of ADAS offers up the most opportunities for Elmos?- Have you considered splitting the role of CEO and CFO to improve investors' assessment of the governance function at Elmos?- What is the plan for the proceeds from the Dortmund fab sale?

Ericsson (Hold, TP SEK 72)- Can you discuss the 5G spending outlook in India given that seems to be a key variable in terms of H2 sales?- How are the signs of life in the European market at present?- You called out intense competition from Chinese vendors in areas like Latin America. How is this developing into 2026? Is there any competitive advantage you have gained yet from leading- edge silicon?- How is the progression to standalone 5G deployments progressing at your largest telecom operator customers?- When should we see developments progress around 6G? How is the industry looking to avoid the hype failures around 5G with 6G?- Is there opportunity to withdraw from certain frontier countries or to reduce costs further beyond what you have already announced?- How can you get the adj EBITA margin up from the current level of around 13% when the mix is likely to get less favourable from here?- Is there a limit to the spending that you will put into the Aduna JV?- There has been considerable, unconfirmed discussions around CEO change in the Swedish press. When does the current CEO's term expire?- If a new CEO was to choose to divest Vonage and/or Cradlepoint, would that be a relatively easy transaction to execute on?

Can you provide us with an updated view on demand across your end markets? Where do you see most scope for a cyclical recovery in the coming 2- 3 quarters? Where do you see remaining downside risks? When do you see the bottom for Geosystems across your 3 major regions? How is the outlook for Manufacturing Intelligence into H2? Should we expect continued good momentum in China but weakness in EMEA? When do you expect to see the bottom in MI in EMEA and what needs to happen for that? How do you look at consensus for Q3 and Q4 given the end market weakness you have seen in H1? Are expectations within the range of what is achievable? You recently launched Aeon - a humanoid robot. Where do you see this product positioned from a technology and performance perspective against Boston Dynamics, Tesla and other robotics players already in the market or planning to launch products in the near future? How do you see the market position and potential for Hexagon here? Can you address all end markets from consumer to industrial or do you have specific market areas in mind? How is the split of Hexagon into two new companies progressing? Looking at the remaining core Hexagon business: Where do you see gaps in the portfolio that may need to be addressed via future acquisitions or organic investments? How can the remaining Hexagon business grow beyond 2025 and where do you see margins progressing medium- term?

- EV momentum in Europe has improved significantly this year while prospects for the US EV market look poor in the light of recent and upcoming policy changes. China continues to grow but recently fears over some OEMs and inventories here (e.g. BYD) have surfaced. How do you look at global momentum for EVs at your Automotive customers currently and into next year? Should we expect the EV growth driver to accelerate for Infineon from here?

- Your CEO commented early August (with FQ3 results) that there is a risk that certain customers may choose to lower their (semis) inventories to unsustainable levels in order to optimize FCF. How has this dynamic evolved since last month and where do you see the biggest risks for headwinds from this (European Auto OEMs)?

- Competition from Chinese semiconductor companies remains a major source of investor concern. Can you share the latest dynamics here across your key product groups and end markets? What do you believe you need to do in order to remain market leader in Auto Semis in China? In this context, how cost competitive do you believe your new fabs (e.g. Kulim, Dresden, Villach) are compared to what Chinese domestic players can achieve?
- How do you assess the current tariff and global trade situation? Where are the major residual risks for Infineon and how can you mitigate some of the tariffs that are affecting you directly?

- How is your AI server power pipeline developing? You have won further long-term business with Nvidia but can you also update us on the pipeline with other customers? How are you doing with the AI-ASIC players in the space and how is traction with hyperscalers beyond Amazon? Once you are hitting the E1b revenue mark next year, how do you see this business growing from there?

- You are making strong progress on the Step Up efficiency program and pricing across your product portfolio is not seeing signs of a more than normal price decline (against historic norms before the semi supply crisis). What does that mean for your long-term 25% through the cycle margin target? What revenue level do you need today to get to 25% margin and what level do you need with Step Up fully completed to get to 30%?

- How do you see your position in the GaN market given increased competition both in foundries/manufacturing but also on the devices/IP side? What does the ruling in Germany against Innoscience mean on a global basis for Infineon? Are you hopeful to win more similar cases elsewhere outside of Germany and China? And from an adoption standpoint: when should we expect more broad-based GaN adoption in Auto?

- How should we look at your M&A strategy following the acquisitions of GaN Systems and Marvell's Ethernet business? Are you still looking for more and which areas are you targeting? Are there still gaps in sensors which you feel you need to address?

H2 order conversion remains a key topic. You confirmed that \(60\%\) of the current backlog (€613m) can be converted into sales in FY25. That implies another €230m of short- cycle orders needed in H2 to meet guidance midpoint. How confident are you about closing that gap? Order intake in Q2 was strong on a headline level, but you mentioned pull- forward effects. Can you provide more color on these? What was the "clean" underlying order intake, and what does that imply for demand visibility into H2 and early 2026? You narrowed your FY25 guidance to the lower half of the original range. What assumptions are now embedded, especially regarding semi demand recovery in H2? What would need to go right for you to still hit the upper end of the new margin range (18- 19.5%)? Tariffs were flagged as a new headwind, with a roughly 50bps margin impact in FY25. Can you elaborate? Which customer groups or product lines are affected, and how much of that can be passed through? Segment margin development continues to diverge. Semiconductor & Advanced Manufacturing remains under pressure, while Biophotonics saw a strong margin rebound. What's driving the strength in Biophotonics? And what are the margin recovery levers in the semi business? The Metrology segment remains weak and was break- even in H1. You mentioned continued softness in auto end- markets - is there any visibility for recovery in 2026? What structural role do you still see for this segment? With Prodmax now no longer expected to be sold in 2025, what does that mean for your portfolio strategy? Are you still committed to streamlining the group around core photonics? Are other assets under strategic review? What is your latest thinking on the strategic role of the Smart Mobility Solutions segment? Given its low profit contribution and capital requirements, could a separation be on the table in the medium term? Your relationship with ASML is a cornerstone of your business. Following recent cautious statements from ASML and slower orders, how has the dialogue evolved? What growth potential do you see beyond 2025? You've implemented cost actions like short- time work and hiring pauses. How much support to margins do you expect from these initiatives in H2? Are they already fully reflected in the updated FY25 guidance? Cash generation improved in H1 on better working capital. Do you expect this trend to continue in H2? Are there additional levers to improve inventory turns or reduce receivables? With the Dresden fab completed, what does your normalized capex profile look like from 2026 onward? Are there any additional capacity expansions planned or under review? Your CMD ambition included a 21- 22% margin target for the group, now delayed by one year to 2026. Given recent downgrades and persistent macro headwinds, how realistic is that ambition from today's perspective? What are the biggest levers to get back on track? Leverage remains around 2.0x. Under what conditions would you consider M&A again? Is medical/life science space still a strategic priority? Looking at long- term megatrends such as quantum, AR/VR, AI and photonics in healthcare - where do you see commercial traction today? Are there any product developments or partnerships worth highlighting?

Can you discuss your bookings momentum in the third quarter at your major tier- 1s and at OEMs within automotive?- Should you revert back to the \(\sim 10\%\) LT sales growth trend in 2026 within automotive?- How is your design win share tracking the core business of magnetic sensors and do you worry about xMR sensors making an impact against all sensors?- Can you discuss your leverage to ADAS and autonomous driving?- Are you concerned around your position in ambient lighting ICs given the potential for new competitors to emerge?- What opportunity could present itself via the ramp of robotics? What share do you have today at the leading Chinese robotics players?- Do you see rising anti- US sentiment in China. Is there opportunity to take share from Allegro Micro in particular within magnetic sensors?- How does X- fab feel about you migrating more wafer volume in China to support your localization strategy?- Can you discuss the threat of Novosense in particular in China? At what point is their quality and scale sufficient to pose a threat to your China business?- Can you discuss the opportunity to recover the gross margin back to the mid- 40s?

Nokia (Buy, TP EUR 4.25)- You lowered your FY- 25 comparable operating profit guide in July primarily on FX, but the range is still quite wide. Can you discuss the risks around H2 as you see them today?- How is book- to- bill trending across Network Infrastructure (NI) after showing improvement in recent quarters? What are the trends within routing and fixed that excite you aside from the proposed BEAD- related investment within fixed?- What opportunities might present themselves in IP routing from the HPE/ Juniper deal?- How has the Infinera deal changed the conversation with hyperscalers? How soon can that business in optical networking with hyperscalers move away from a heavy dependence on the relatively competitive and low- margin DCI space?- What are your plans to improve the very low fab utilization at the InP fab of Infinera that you have inherited?- Can you discuss your book- to- bill trends in Mobile Networks (MN) and what gives you confidence that €8bn of segment sales is enough to support required R&D spend?- The MN segment seems sub- scale especially in the USA, even after the T- Mobile USA deal. How can you claw back scale in MN across the globe to get this segment back to returning its cost of capital? How do you see the impact of AI on developments around 6G RAN?- What exciting developments can develop within the Cloud & Network Services (CNS) segment in the next 3- 5 years?- What opportunities remain to grow Technologies sales from the current run- rate of €1.4bn on an annualised basis?- What is your initial impression of the new CEO and the likely, adjusted strategic direction for the company? Is Nokia going to become more "American" as a company?

Following a stronger H1 and recent Q3 guide, it appears growth of \(>25\%\) is achievable for Nordic in 2025. This is far ahead of your more 'modest' expectations of around \(+15\%\) outlined during the Sep- 24 CMD. Can you help investors understand what has driven upside here, and how much of this could be driven by pull- ins - which has been evidenced at your biggest customers like Logitech & Apple (both \(>10\%\) of sales)?

Can you explain the rationale behind recent acquisitions of Memfault and Neuton.A.I, and what appears to be an accelerated transition from a 'product' company to a 'solutions' company? What's driving this strategy & how do you manage risks related to competing more directly with your customers?

How important is the launch of Apple's new AirTags (in Sep- 25, reportedly) for Nordic in H2- 25 and 2026? The last launch was nearly 5 years ago, whilst AirTags are seemingly coming off a digestion phase.

Can you discuss share trends against competitors like Silicon Labs in important categories like ESL and CGM, and risks of future share loss to new BLE entrants like Ambiq? How will the launch of the nRF54 series help Nordic regain share.

Can you provide an update on the launch of the nRF54 series and how design activity has progressed on both the 54L & 54H series. How will this new product series impact volumes and revenue growth over 2026 & 2027? What is the ASP premium for the 54H, and how should we think about the cross- selling opportunities (i.e. with Nordics PMIC solutions) within advanced applications?

In terms of cellular, how have efforts to lower pricing impacted demand in recent quarters? Also, have you seen greater traction in western markets following recent restrictions on Chinese vendors (ie Quectel was recently blacklisted)? Lastly, do you need to expand beyond NB- IoT (ie in 5G RedCap) to meet your \(\) 100\$ sales target in 2028?

You've noted good design activity for the nRF54 series in China. Is this driven by share gains (from US peers like Silicon Labs, Texas Instruments, etc) in light of current geopolitical tensions, or the fact the local players are still behind at the high- end?

Can you discuss the parts of the consumer end- market that are through the worst of the inventory correction. Are recent signs of improvement concentrated in one region and would you call out any particular strength such as in wearables and PC peripherals?
What opportunities for greater BLE adoption would you call out that could be significant, such as LE Audio?

Can you discuss how Nordic plays into the edge AI concept as a low- data rate, short- range wireless company compared with those competitors with broader portfolios and more established positions in sensor fusion? Would you need to partner with larger, industrial- focused MCU companies for example in industrial scenarios where you might have an AI- enabled gateway that drew on a number of sensors. How can you be sure that BLE is the key enabling connectivity technology versus WiFi?

You have presented your new strategy and medium- term ambitions at the CMD just before the conference. Can you summarize the key takeaways for us? What were the main new elements compared to the 2024 CMD? Metrology accounted for \(\sim 50\%\) of H1 order intake and seems to be developing faster than initially guided. What has changed since last year, and how should we think about the pace of revenue conversion into 2026? You mentioned that you are already delivering tools to three major semi players and are in advanced qualification with two more. Without naming names, can you provide a bit more detail on what this means in terms of potential revenue concentration and timing of larger rollouts? How do you see your competitive positioning in scanning acoustic microscopy (SAM) compared to other inspection technologies? What differentiates your tools for advanced packaging and hybrid bonding lines? Lead times in metrology are just 3- 4 months. Does this imply more volatility in reported backlog compared to your traditional business? How do you plan to manage visibility and investor expectations around that? You have engaged in M&A (Desconpro, DIVE) and cooperations (Sentech, imec), broadening your expertise. Can you elaborate on your strategy? Q2 order intake was the strongest since Q4- 23, and the backlog has stabilized around €140m. How much of that can realistically be converted into sales in H2? To what extent do industrial orders, with their longer lead times, stretch into 2026? You guided towards the lower end of the FY25 forecast range, but stressed confidence in H2 based on the order book. What growth assumptions are embedded for H2, and where do you see the biggest risks to delivery? Industrial order intake nearly doubled in H1, driven by aerospace, energy and graphite purification. How sustainable is this momentum, and what role do you see for industrial systems in your long- term growth strategy, given the increasing focus on semiconductors? Lead times in industrial are 12- 18 months. What does this imply for the margin trajectory in that segment, and is there scope for additional outsourcing or efficiency gains? With the last major silicon crystal growth order now completed, what is the outlook for this business? Do you expect significant new orders before 2027, or is this more of a strategic optionality until demand returns? You mentioned new R&D initiatives in wide- bandgap materials, especially aluminium nitride (AIN). How advanced are these efforts, and when could they start to contribute commercially? EBITDA margin declined sharply in Q2, reflecting higher OpEx from strategic investments. How much of this cost ramp will carry into 2026, and when do you expect to see operating leverage kicking in again? Free cash flow should be negative in 2025 due to capex and working capital build- up. How comfortable are you with the balance sheet? Where do you see the largest opportunities for metrology - e.g., in Al/HPC, 3D integration, or even in emerging markets like quantum computing? Do you view PVA TePla primarily as a pure- play metrology company in the medium term, or do you still see crystal growth and industrial systems as important pillars in your long- term portfolio strategy?

In Region 1, what is the underlying performance in Italy vs the US? Region 2 has seen growth slow sequentially since Q4/24 through to Q2/25, how much has exposure to Retail, Automotive & Manufacturing been a factor in recent weakness? Is there any sign of improvement? In Region 3 there has been a divergence in performance between the UK (growing well) and France (weaker). How is the UK trending on an organic basis? What is driving that? France remains weaker - are there any signs of improvement? What efforts are being made to turn this around?

In Q2 you did not give the usual sector trends - which sectors remain strong? Where has there been more weakness? Many peers have talked to more hesitancy to start new projects, impacting growth - how has customer behaviour changed? What type of projects is there demand for and what types of projects is there less willingness to press ahead with? Do you anticipate any recovery in the demand environment through Q3/4? The majority of your contracts are fixed price, particularly in Region 1 - but have you been experiencing negative pricing pressure, particularly in regions with a higher proportion of T&M pricing?

How are clients seeking to use agentic AI tools? Can you give some examples of projects with customers? How significant is generative AI to group revenue? How have the ways that clients are exploring and implementing generative AI within their own businesses changed over the last couple of years? You've highlighted the benefit to Reply from greater automation and use of AI tools internally - how much of this are you expecting to share with the customer in terms of pricing?

You previously communicated the potential for a larger acquisition, what scale of opportunities are you looking at? The US has previously highlighted as a target region for M&A - does this remain the case? Are there any other key geographies that you would look to build scale in inorganically? What are the key criteria for assessing opportunities? Are you seeking any particular capabilities, or exposure to key customers, verticals or vendors? Have there been any particular learnings from previous acquisitions that have been less strong for the group? Can you give an update on the performance of Solirius (acquired Nov 2024)? Would you look to acquire further public sector exposure in the UK?

- Customer inventory levels still seem very high in both logic and memory? When do you think this situation will normalise itself?- How is your loading today of 300mm polished and 300mm epi wafers?- Will you start by ramping FabNext for 300mm epi? If you choose to delay the ramp again, could you supply advanced 300mm epi out of Freiberg?- How is the migration of trailing-edge volumes from the West to China at 300mm affecting your loading at 28-65nm? Do you supply SMIC and HH Grace?- How do you assess the likely success of GlobalWafers' expansion plan in Texas?- Have you seen any companies willing to let LTAs lapse given the potential to extract price concessions for offering up higher allocations?- Is there any further cost saving potential from reducing 200mm capacity?- When are you obliged to disclose the covenants around your debt? You are trending into the 3-4x range (net debt/EBITDA), where covenants typically sit for German industrial companies?- How much more capital spend is required to build FabNext to full capacity?- Would Wacker Chemie likely approve a rights issue if you decided to push forward with one in H1-26?

Softbank Group (Buy, TP JPY 20,000)- The company holds \(90\%\) of Arm, and over the last year you have been buying Ampere, invested in NVIDIA and Intel. Are these recent moves trades or long- term positions?- Can you explain the rationale and aims for each of the three investments?- What is the long- term vision of what you hope to achieve in the semiconductor area?- Why not just drive all chip investment through Arm?- Arm's fluctuating value significantly impacts SoftBank's NAV. Is that sensitivity something the company accepts as inevitable, or would you like a different balance of assets ahead?- What do you see as the blue sky scenario for Arm, that has led it to perform so well since IPO.- Stargate was announced as a USD500bn project, is that still the target?- There were reports that you want to use Arm chips at Stargate. Is that correct? What is the significance of that to Arm?- You have announced that you have found your first site, will this be a small scale test, or something larger?- In Japan, SoftBank Corp is developing Sharp's LCD plant, into a large scale AI Infrastructure Data Center, and plans to turn the area into an AI industrial zone. Is Stargate thinking big in such a way, or is it focused on the AI infrastructure only?- Share Buyback: You've repurchased over \(30 billion in stock and canceled over 20\%\) of your outstanding shares since 2020, with you now pivoting to investment mode should we expect buybacks to be on pause?- The NAV discount has narrowed recently to in line with the lows of the last five years, why do you think this has occurred? Are you attracting a new group of shareholders?- In the Vision Funds, what are your largest investments, and what is the monetization outlook? What is the cash runway of investee companies?- Strategic Importance of Telecom Holdings: Softbank Corp, T-Mobile and Deutsche Telekom have positively contributed to SoftBank's NAV. What is the long- term strategy for these telecom holdings, and how do they fit into SoftBank's overall portfolio?

- Who is responsible for the high level of excess wafer inventory held at your largest foundries, notably in RF SOI? Should you have been more understanding around deferring wafer volumes under contract?- Is it not the case that your largest foundries have no incentive to re-build wafer inventories until stocks go below 6 months from 12 months today?- When could Broadcom move POI into production in filters?- Is there a scenario where mmWave is de-specified from US-market iPhones that you are considering as a possibility?- Can you discuss the opportunities ahead with your SOI business via the ramp-up of silicon photonics (SiPho)?- China appears to have become competitive on 300mm wafer supply in raw silicon for trailing edge, even if quality is not there. Are you concerned around SOI wafer supply copy-cats in China emerging?- What opportunity is there at the Taiwanese and Chinese foundries to broaden out their SOI offering?- If ST Micro gives up on SmartSiC, would you too? When will SmartSiC be in production?- What cost saving potential is there from squeezing your wafer suppliers on price?- Why is your capex spend so high, despite declining sales? Should not be taking a more aggressive view on costs including capex outside of POI and SiPho?

You lowered your margin guidance after Q2, citing one- offs but also suggesting a weaker mix and softer H2. Can you clarify how much of the margin downgrade is temporary vs structural? What would it take to return to the original EBIT margin range of \(15 - 17\%\) ? Order intake came in quite soft in Q2 and you referred to 2023/24 as "exceptionally strong years"—should we interpret this as a step- down in underlying demand? To what extent is this driven by digestion phases at clients vs clients waiting for your upcoming tool launches? Photomask orders dropped sharply in Q2, with no orders from China. Do you still expect a recovery in this segment ahead of the launch of your new mid- end tool next year? How is the backlog by region currently distributed? Your UV scanner business remains strong and you're expanding capacity for a key customer. Do you see signs of share gains here? What feedback do you get on performance of your new scanner vs the competition? You've flagged significant product transition activity in 2026, including Photomask and UV Scanners. Are you concerned that clients may delay orders until the new tools are released? What kind of ramp timeline are you planning for? The hybrid border tool was presented this summer. What feedback have you received from potential customers so far? When do you expect the first volume orders? Is your \(20 - 30\%\) market share target still realistic? You mentioned in the call that temporary border demand is softening. Could this be a structural shift, or do you see further waves of investment coming—e.g., for HBM4E or HBM5? The recent margin pressure in Advanced Backend was partly due to customer mix. How confident are you that this normalizes in H2 or 2026? Could the ramp- up of higher- margin new tools fully offset this effect? You reaffirmed your FY25 sales guidance of €470- 510m, implying a yoy decline in H2. How should we think about the balance between backlog conversion vs expected short- cycle orders? You flagged selective underutilization of production from late 2025. Is this driven by temporary bonders, or broader across the portfolio? How flexibly can you adjust your cost base? Softening margins and working capital have weighed on cash flow, but you still guide for \(>€20m\) FCF in FY25. What are the moving pieces to get there? Is working capital normalization tracking as planned? You continue to invest heavily in strategic projects (new fab, ERP, product development). At the CMD in November, will you introduce a new forecast horizon beyond 2025—and will capital allocation (e.g. M&A, buybacks) also be part of the agenda? With many new tools being launched and others in ramp mode, what internal KPIs do you track to ensure project execution remains on track and resources are properly allocated? You mentioned being involved in major upcoming fab projects. Can you share anything on the timing and potential size of these opportunities? Will they be more relevant in 2026 or already in H2 2025? What are the major levers for margin expansion into 2026 and beyond? How much of that comes from product mix vs structural efficiency improvements?

- How is the role of test evolving with the accelerated adoption advanced packaging, chiplets and AI silicon in high-performance compute (HPC)? How should investors think about the increasing 'cost of failure' in these domains, and how this drives greater test intensity?- Can you explain the building blocks behind your recently introduced mid-term targets (sales of €850-900m, EBITDA margins of 38-40%, by 2028). How do you plan to reduce the dilutive nature of recent acquisitions (DIS, Harbor Electronics), and what was the rationale behind these acquisitions?- Can you help investors understand your opportunity in High Bandwidth Memory (HBM)? Why do you foresee a transition from micro-cantilever probe cards to Vertical MEMS? What are the limitations of the current HBM test flow & probe card technologies, and how does this evolve with HBM4/4E & beyond? Lastly, is the adoption of Hybrid bonding a tailwind for Vertical MEMS probe card adoption in HBM?- Can you provide an update your qualification process and your assumption for first HBM sales? How do you expect this market to be split between Technoprobe, FormFactor and any other competitors (ie JEM, etc)?- At what stage of test are you currently being qualified on in HBM? Is it for wafer-level tests (ie for each DRAM wafer, before dies are diced & stacked) and/or performance tests for singulated HBM stacks? Are there any other stages of test that investors should think about in HBM where Technoprobe can be inserted?- How has your AI exposure (specifically AI GPUs & ASICs) evolved as a % of revenues over the past 3 years? How do you expect this to evolve over the coming years? You have \(\sim 100\%\) share at Nvidia today for testing their AI GPUs, but how should we think about share loss to FormFactor as they aim to get qualified?- Technoprobe holds \(\sim 60\%\) share in Vertical MEMS probe cards used in advanced logic, but you have majority share in AI GPUs at Nvidia. Can you help us understand what differentiates you here vs your main competitors, and what are the new challenges involved in AI testing (ie larger die sizes, power constraints, thermal control, etc)?- Can you help investors understand your opportunity within custom ASICs, as hyperscalers ramp more volume? How much exposure do you have today as a % of revenue, and who are the main customers you are in dialogue with today? Do you have or expect to gain majority share at these customers as well?- How should investors think about your leverage to edge AI, given that you have \(50\%\) exposure to smartphone & PCs? Beyond driving higher volume (via a faster replacement cycle), does edge AI drive up test intensity & complexity in these domains?- Key peers in test, Teradyne and Advantest, recently acquired significant stakes in Technoprobe. What is the rationale behind these strategic partnerships (e.g. rising test complexity requiring more collaboration through the test supply chain)?

Your growth expectations for 2025 appear to have moderated from the start of the year, partly on FX. How comfortable are you with your recently revised 2027 sales target of CHF1.5- 1.7bn, which assumes a sales CAGR of \(+17 - 22\%\) over FY24- 27. Can you help investors understand the drivers to the upper & lower end of this range. For example, is the higher- end dependent on a resumption in greenfield capacity expansion in NAND during 2026?

You recently adjusted your mid- term EBITDA margin target to \(30 - 37\%\) (from \(32 - 37\%\) ) to account for headwinds like FX and lower operating leverage. Can you help investors understand the drivers to the upper & lower end of this range? Specifically, how significant will your Malaysian ramp be in terms of driving higher profitability out to 2027- 29?

Can you discuss your China exposure, both direct Chinese OEMs and indirect via Western equipment vendors? How much does China contribute to sales & profitability, and how do you expect this to trend over the next few years.

In light of recent policy recommendations in the US concerning semicap sub- system providers, what scenario for further US/China export controls or trade restrictions concerns you the most? Would you be willing to only offer let's say 5 year old tech to the Chinese OEMs if requested by your largest tier- 1 OEMs, and/or Western government authorities?

Can you help us understand the competitiveness of Chinese OEMs vs wester peers, as well as the competitiveness of Chinese valve manufacturers like Kinglai and Jingsheng vs VAT. How many years away are they from matching VAT on quality, scale & serviceability?

Can you discuss share of wallet improvements with next- generation etch and deposition platforms supporting logic/foundry inflections like gate all around (GAA), backside power delivery (BPD), and future transitions like Complementary Field- Effect Transistors (CFET) and 3DDRAM? What percentage of the tool's BOM can you go to and from?
Can you discuss progress in terms of expanding into adjacencies, such as motion controls (lifters), valve modules, gas inlet valves for ALD, pressure measurement and control etc?
To what extent does it make sense to team up closer with adjacent domains such as vacuum, sensors and process control controlled by the likes of Atlas Copco, Pfeiffer, Inficon & MKS?

Your old leadership appeared to focus on bolt- on acquisitions in sensors/ software of relatively low value. How does new leadership see the role of M&A as a means of expanding the addressable market? Are there attractive segments in non- semi that could help you to diversify exposure?

How should investors think about the impact of FX on sales & profitability, for example, for a \(10\%\) change in the USD/EUR? Furthermore, how are key input costs such as aluminium, elastomers trending at present.

WISE (Hold, TP GBp 990)- How do you view stablecoins evolution, specifically in B2B with FX elements?- Do you see it mainly as a threat or could this be an opportunity for Wise?- Central banks are increasingly developing real- time gross settlements systems and CBDCs. How do you position Wise to remain relevant when correspondent banking friction potentially disappears or reduces?- Beyond price and transparency, what do you see as the most defensible moat in your business over the next 3- 5 years?- Where do you see Wise's effective take rate stabilizing, and should we think about scale- driven cost efficiency offsetting that?- Are you planning to diverse your pricing model? If so, which customer cohort (retail, SME, Platform/API) would contribute most to incremental profitability, and how does that shape where you are investing?- How do you approach capital allocation decisions between geo expansion, product development, and potential adjacencies?- Given your asset- light model, how do you evaluate the trade- offs between organic growth investments, potential acquisitions of complementary capabilities, and returning capital to shareholders?- How are you thinking about the infrastructure investments needed to maintain competitive advantages in speed and transparency?- Are you prepared to accept lower rates in weaker geos to sustain growth, or do you prefer to preserve regional profitability even if that caps growth?- How sensitive is your business model to further interest rate cuts, and what is your hedge strategy?- How do you plan to maintain competitive differentiation as the market commodities?

The Equity Rating Dispersion Chart depicts the following:

The proportion of recommendations that are rated "buy", "sell" and "hold" over the previous 12 months. This is shown for securities issued in the stated region e.g. "Europe Universe". See rating definitions below. This is represented by the "Companies Covered" bars in the chart. The percentage value displayed above the bar is the proportion as a percentage. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "buy" / "Companies Covered" bar means that \(50\%\) of DB's equity research covered companies over the past 12 months have a "buy" rating.
Next to each of the three respective bars showing the proportion of "buy", "sell" and "hold" recommendations we provide two additional bars to show:

- The proportion of "buy", "sell" or "hold recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates provided MIFID Investment or Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. This is represented in the "MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the given rating where DB has also provided MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated have also received MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services from DB.

- The proportion of "buy" (or "sell" or "hold) recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates has provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months for which it has received compensation. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the stated rating where DB has also provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ Investment Banking relationship" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated also have an Investment Banking Relationship with DB.
Buy: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors buy the stock.
Sell: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors sell the stock.
Hold: We take a neutral view on the stock 12- months out and, based on this time horizon, do not recommend either a Buy or Sell.
TSR = Total Shareholder Return. Percentage change in share price from current price to projected target price plus projected dividend yield

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.
